number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is my 3rd and final revision to my review for the game Call to Arms. I first reviewed it fairly early in its development (July 31st 2015) and then again, a year later, after a few anticipated updates came out. (August 16th 2016) As it stands now, the “hot topic” is the games decision to go Free 2 Play whilst introducing numerous micro-transaction based add-ons. This has no bearing on my final assessment towards the game. I will admit that I am not crazy about these new developments, I do agree that going Free 2 Play was almost necessary at this point. It has an extremely small player base, and as someone who exclusively plays online only this became a major issue; not the only issue, but a significant one. The game is rather dull. I find it uninspiring, unimaginative, repetitive, and generally lackluster all the way around. It is lacking. Two Major factions, neither very impressive or thought out, units that seemingly only differ in name, maps that are lackluster and overly cluttered in a nonsensical fashion. Sound effects that are more annoying then immersive; the list just goes on and on. Bottom line is it just doesn’t offer much. In some areas quantity is lacking and in other areas (most) quality is lacking. No one plays the game. As stated above the player base is extremely small, even with sales of up to 80% the game has failed to gain traction. If you play single player this won’t really effect you in any way but it killed the online community. Some may say going F2P will remedy this issue, I personally think the game is lacking too much in other departments to merit popularity but only time will tell. As the game is now free, try it for yourself, my opinion is just that, an opinion.

Early Access Review
								This reminds me of Full Spectrum Warrior but with an RTS camera and higher level of control.  The object of the game is the same: find the enemy, fix the enemy, flank the enemy.  You essentially use your teams and the environment to gain an advantage on your adversary and destroy them before they do the same to you.  I've only played a single skirmish so far, but I had a ton of fun!  This seems to be exactly what I've been looking for in a thinking man's strategy game.  Definitely recommend so far!

Early Access Review
								(3/27/17) Edit: Recently bought the game, before this edit I still recommended the game as a free version. Now that I bought it I still recommend it.This game is like Men of War Assault Squad 2 but is even more fps like.There are only 10 missions only for the US faction and most of those missions suck/are boring, the capture objectives type missions are basically non-existant which to me was the best part of MOWAS2.  The coolest thing about this game is that it has an enhanced 3rd/1st person camera that was featured in the tank battle map of MOWAS2 but alot of people here think that is the worst thing about the game. I think it is cool, you can play the game like an early 2000's fps (sort of).The stupid unlock system for units where you have to play over like 1000 games seems to be in Call to Arms too which is bad. I would say it is worth $30 bucks if you get all the dlc for free (which this company loves dlc). I'm pretty sure I and other players who play this casually will get over 100 - 200 hours in this easily. I wouldn't shell out $60 bucks for this though, only buy it on sale for the price everyone else paid for it ($30 bucks).Will continue to edit throughout time.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
Early Access Review
								First and foremost... Let me say that, dont listen to the amount of reviews. While writing this, the Recent/Overall Reviews are both "Mixed". Main reason is, idiots that bought the game went and whined. Because of this little idiotic outburst from kids who doesnt understand the term "review", the game is hardly populated.Download the game, Play couple of matches against A.I. then against players, and make an actual review.I have to say... I was personally about to skip this game from tests because of the "Mixed" reviews...Now to the actual review...The game is surprisingly good for an Early Access Game... The F2P version of the game only includes MultiplayerSkirmish (VS.A.I.), Tutorial (Which is really nothing else than 1v1 against an A.I.) and thats it... But its enough for me from EAG thats F2P. The full game consist of again Campaign, Coop, some "faction unlocks" (i dont know) and access to Workshop (Tho I think theres a way to bypass this... Dunno). 30€ to get these unlocked is not worth it currently... So this list is pretty much "Pros/Cons" compressed.The A.I is really random, and the unit movement and coding is a bit "oh for ♥♥♥♥s sakes.." kind of coding.With "random A.I.", I mean A.I. that doesnt seem to play logically or strategically at all. They seem to spawn units in a pretty simple order and move them randomly to points where they are surely gonna get annihilated. Or they cap a point and defend it by just standing there for no reason, making it easy for you to just rush in from the sides. They flank themselves (As in, they leave the point, go around the point to their side of the compound, and re-enter from their side) which usually gets most of them killed by my Marksmen or Sniper ambushers... Any armored vehicle is easy to break by literally just rushing it from 2 sides at the same time (Works most of the times), then take cover on the vehicle itself and throw some nades inside and hit the deck.A.I. difficulty doesn't seem to be "Extreme" when set to. Its more like Hard with extra-bit of resources.Playing against players should be something you should do after getting to know with the basics. Youre probably gonna get ravaged couple of times, but just ask some tips and they should give you some (as long as theyre not some asian or russian idiots)And thats pretty much it... The game is something you should play and learn if youve been a fan of MoW's. At first it might feel like its a full reskin of the game, but bear with it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Same type of deal as Men of War, a highly granular RTS with a lot of robust mechanics and features.Difference here is that it's set in modern times and features some improvements. Tanks get tracked on terrain if you aren't careful, direct control works more like a TPS rather than a isometric shooter now, ammo management is entirely different, amongst some other changes mostly minor QoL stiff.A lot of negative reviews due to the devs halfway through the development cycle creating a season pass for DLC. Devs made it explicitly clear there would be no DLC released while the game was still in early access, and that everybody who bought the game was going to get all the factions for multiplayer, but people like to be outraged about nothing I guess.I recommend the game when it releases if you enjoyed any of the Men of War games.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've tried many of the MoW type games and not really enjoyed them. So far this is proving an exception.A big factor for me is the ability to include AI players in multiplayer games, essentially giving me the singleplayer skirmish mode I so longed for in the other Men of War type games. The sounds and graphics are way more polished than what I had seen from the other titles but in some ways this only draws more attention to the clunky old animations left over from the older games.I absolutely love this game's take on the Men of War direct control system. The version in this game is much more intuitive and immersive, though it only affects vehicles right now. It is to be hoped that these changes make their way to the control of infantry as well.As someone who hates playing things online, I profoundly resent the levelling system which does not allow you to use more advanced units until you've reached a certain level that, as I understand it, requires ranked online play. It should be possible to use all units if you're not playing online.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Call to arms revisited. So having sunk a ton of hours into the multiplayer of call to arms and being a huge fan of the men of war series in general I will try to explain my experience. While the game is clearly not done as most of unit discriptions still say squad1,squad2 ect. the game is a little confusing as you are really unaware of what units are good , and what they do exactly. the game balance needs some work and arguebly the GRM are the best faction. Having better units means nothing to experienced players when overwelming firepower is the asnswer to almost all your porrblems. The pricing is my main arrguement it just costs too much for the usa to really compete and countless times I have swarmed or been swarmed by sheer numbers. The counter is play really good, better then your opponent. which isn't really fun. One mistake can find you behind on the buys and next thing you know vehicles are in play and you don't have any AT. but this goes for both factions. Veterans of men of war will find it's basicly the same old game. However those players ususally suck, and wont take the time to see the differrences in tactics and gameplay. War has changed, the importance of position is everything and finding the perfect flanking cover is the key to not watching your men get gunned down immediately. It's like all the inf have mg 42s and moving around is easier said then done. The new direct control feature is flipping terrible, and ai pathing really needs work. but these things are being slowly addressed and fixed. I recommend this game, if only to kill you one time in multiplayer because the community is split between god like players and the worst players on earth. This game is something different it's not men of war with new skins, its men of war with a modern theme. People give them♥♥♥♥♥♥for using the same game engine as mowas2 but at least it's not the same maps same units, it's unique and fun in it's own right. So buy this game, maybe not now but in the future, when it's more complete. You might hate it but jsut remember you suck and getting better takes time. See you on the battlefield ♥♥♥♥♥es.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Over the past fews months this has been in early access, some have critized this game as being essentially "Men of War: Assault Squad: Modern Assault Mod: The Game." I can see where that comes from, but I don't see it being the case. I just feel I should lend some thoughts on the game so far.The ModYes, it certainly does look like the Modern Assault mod for Assault Squad 2. However, it is simply not a mod. Go here if you want to see it for yourself: 


Modern Assault 
A Workshop Item for Men of War: Assault Squad 2
By: Vora_bat

			Modern modification (ex modern pack) for Assault Squad 2. Current development status: FROZEN Size: 700 mb Includes: - 2 single player missions - 9 refactored multiplayer maps - 2 multiplayer factions (USA vs Russia) - A...		


 There are plenty of vehicle, weapon, and soldier assets made for the mod, but they are just not the quality you will get out of a dedicated studio. The maps and some assets are repurposed, so eastern and western European structures appear in a modern setting more often than not. Not to say that architure doesn't exist in present day. You could say that is just the theater of war for a specific battle, but a mix of original and recycled models, assets, and such can you only get you so far. Digitalmindsoft takes the great concept and presents it in full force. The mod's development is also frozen, so don't expect more content and improvements out of it any time soon.The GameThis is a game, therefore it includes things you would expect of a game. All of the assets are professionally modelled, recorded, and maintained. A full-fledged modern campaign is in the works. It has dedicated servers, courtesy of SteamWorks. It will be featuring a secret-services themed DLC, which will be available to those who purchase the game in its early-access state, free of charge. That, on top of game engine, interface, and mechanics improvements. So on and so forth. In terms of unit count, you can expect that of Men of War games: plenty of diverse units, weapons, vehicles, equipment, and, in this case, weapon accessories. So, flashlights, lasers, silencers, and the like. You also make use of a nightvision view for when the map cycles to night. You can also host local games against AI, which was sorely lacking in previous games. That is a plus from me.SummaryDigitalmindsoft is going out on a little limb here in publishing this game themselves, but I think they have faired well so far. They have been consistent, responsive, and rather frequent with their Dev Updates. Their 14th Dev Update was March 11th, and they have made great strides in asking the community what we want next (what vehicles, modes, etc.), implementing new graphic technologies, improving multiplayer competitivness (in terms of gamemodes, I don't care for the leveling system), releasing the missions of the campaign for testing for those who purchased the Deluxe Edition, and all around keeping us informed as to where our money is going in this critical time for the game. There has been controversy over things like the 3rd person control mode, bullet damage models, and the like, but it all seems to be leading to the betterment of the game.Truely, with games these days often having a retail cost of $60 (RTS, FPS, etc), its, previously $20 price, now $25 price is still rather generous, if I do say so myself. And, I don't know about you, but I have always wanted a modern version of Men of War, and it grants that wish pretty well. Last time I checked (5 months ago), there wasn't a very high multiplayer population, but maybe that is because it is still in early access. That is not too detrimental for me, because you can now host local lobbies with AI, which is a good time, and I primarily play these games for the campaign. Still, some may not take very kindly to this. Nonetheless, It still maintains that unique Men of War RTS DNA, and I just think this game deserves a bit more love from the community.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game during the recent steam sale, I cannot believe how cheap it was. Under 7$ for one of the best rts games I have ever played, admittedly it is missing some polish, and could use other factions/more units. Even that said, I would have paid full price if I heard of it sooner.Tactically very sound and graphically very pretty(Though has some stutter issues). This game is a micro managers wet dream. The ai in this game is a real challenge as well. Playing the Co-Op gamemode evacuation can come down to just a few soldiers, causing you to micro manage your medics and have your riflemen improvise and pick up other units weapons to use against them.Thats right, in this game every soldier has an inventory, not every UNIT, but every individual soldier. This allows you to go as far as to pick up spare rounds, bandages and grenades, you can also manage the inventory of vehicles. You can split these units up how you see fit, garrisoning them in seperate buildings to create firing arc's etc. Controlling units individually is also a thing, simply hold control and you are in for some serious gameplay. Use every truck, tank, and individual to the fullest by firing manually on targets, this allows precise firing on various buildings etc. Not to mention it is a huge breath of fresh air to see a unique feature like this added to rts games. A bit of action combat essentially adds another layer to the game, especially in multiplayer when some guy is precision sniping your vital mg's and medics.All in all the game is worth full price, and most I have run into from the steam sale would agree. Played for many hours yesterday and I am about to boot this up again! Defnitely worth a buy if you are a fan of tactical rts and teamwork.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Playing this RTS is really fun and the ingame unit UI is similar to "Men of War" but there are still so many issues I have with this game. I've had this game since it was released on steam as a pre-alpha or whatever they call it and I had high hopes for this game but after many updates...1. The main menus is so cluttered that I almost always want to quit as soon as I open the game.2. Creating a local/online skirmish has so little options and is tucked away in the bottom left corner of the screen while the rest of the screen is cluttered with stuff... Literally I have to squint at my 32" desktop screen to try and select the few options when setting up a game.3. You cant change the draw distance in game. This means that all you know is that there are some units over there but you have to scroll over to the area to see what it is. Not to mention that you can't change this in the settings...4. It has workshop support but is so hard to use and navigate to activate the mods that its not worth it. For some reason in the lastest version that I just played you have to go to settings and then click on the "mods" tab, then move the mods you want to activate from the deactivated list to activated list and hit accept...? Why can't it be at the top of the main menus like the other tabs? Why does it have to be hidden way back in the settings? Not to mention the settings button is hard to see because the main menus is so cluttered...Now Good things about the game:1. AI are smart and very fun to play against2. The cover system works and you can send units to take cover in buildings3. Everything is highly detailed!!4. The unit UI makes sense because it is exactly like 'Men of War'5. The campaign is fun. Not anything revolutionary but fun.In short, game play is your typical RTS and most RTSs are fun but if you hate cluttered UIs or main menus then gl hf dd.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Up-dated review Jan/8/2016. Current build of the game is playable, however, In order to play any mods you need to revert to a previous version of the game. at this stage though it's very buggy but it is alpha still. It seems like Instinct has started listening to veteran players about issues in game which is awesome and the fact that IMO the best modder for this franchise is now on the dev team # SirHinkel this game could shape up to be pretty epic.Review in depth (this is still a work in progress game so I will write a final once it is finished)Gameplay: Single player is super fun, Missions are bugggy but playable some balance needs to happen still such as            insane rates of fire for bmp/bradley and fix the hit boxes on some of the aiming with direct control. The new direct control: is pretty buggy still IMO it's worse than the original, however, you can use your mouse wheel to zoom into a kind of 3rd person view and can literally snipe anything on the map making direct control aiming soo much easier. I still think that it should be optional to use both I know I would like the option to switch between the two for movement and for shooting ( the new system makes it tricky to position and fire on the move) AI behaviour and pathing: Much better than MOWAS2 however you better have your anti tank units on hold fire or they will waste their precious rockets againts infantry. The new grenade system is fun, it shows the arc of your throw. Some balance needs to happen and some realism issues are abound too. such as there are no infantry units at least in the US Army that uses smg's I was in the Infantry for 10 years. Stealth has never been a strong point in the game if this is going to be a thing I suggest making the mission specific units more accurate or powerful to negate the derpy AI behavior when attacking or moving. Vehicles still take the worst paths available such as driving over weapons or ammo boxes. Infantry still has horrible pathing but oh well. Inventory and ammo re-supply system: It's been dumbed down, but the new version isn't too bad the ammo for the weapon is actually in the weapon so the automatic re-supoply fills it up instead of putting individual rifle/MG ammo in your inventory. The Auto re-supply as had an overhaul and works a lot faster so you can get your precious elite units back on the line quicker. I miss the old system but this new one grew on me and I like it now too.Graphics: actually looks better and runs better than AS2. I run this game on a mid-range normal person computer so it's playable on medium settings or higher for textures without the extra sprinkle options. and to be honest I would rather be playing a video game then doing this new age VR stuff anyway. I'm sure when I get Oprah rich and can offord a 3000$ rig I will change my tune. Mod support: Currently broken and have to play on a previous version of the game so it's un-playable unless you revert.Multiplayer: Level lock and honestly I hate MP in strategy games unless it's a co-op mission so read other  reviews for in-depth MP aspects of this game. Overall: This game still has a lot of potential and good enough that I had to change my intial negative re-view to a positive.

								Call to Arms to an Modern RTS set in the middle east, made by the devs of the wonderful WW2 Men Of War RTS titles.I highly recomend this for men of war vets, and stratgey fans. 								There is nothing differentiating this game from Men of War. Nothing at all besides Call to Arms being in modern times. Aspects of the UI are pulled directly from MoW, pictures and graphics are pulled right from Men of War as well. Because it's worth the fraction of the full price I paid for it.Just go buy some of the Men of War games, they are actually playable, you can understand what's going on, and they are actually complete. Then when this game is complete, and those stolen elements are replaced with unique elements this game might be worth while to get.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is my first review and I must say I really really do love the game but you do get the occaisonal disconnects from servers and such. As for server population, it is usually quite low. There are always less than 300 people in game when I am on and sometimes it can take a while to find a game room to fill up. The game is decently optimized (though the graphics aren't super beautiful) and I'm able to run it at high/ultra settings with AA off at 1440p with an r7 360 at 40+ fps. The gameplay that i've been able to play has been fun and AI isn't horridly stupid so that's good (though sometimes they take the path right into the line of fire when there is another way behind cover). For a game in early access it has a decent amount of content and there are plenty of mods out there to make it more exciting such as more maps, "tactical" mode to make it a bit more challenging, etc. I'm excited to see what comes and I hope more people will play so servers are more populated! And I hope the devs will fix the occaisional crashes and disconnecting issues.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Right now it plays like Men of War... with BIGGER GUNSModern setting means infantry wields assault weaponry putting out a lot of fire and vehicles are all large caliber weapon platforms on wheels with different kind of shells, guided missiles and smoke launchers.Plus the recently added (and heavily WIP) Armored Warfare is a MP game mode that is all about controlling tanks, with infantry taking only a secondary role. Direct control was also improved for that - now you can control your vehicle almost through first person perspective, arcade-style, which is pretty fun.The one major downside is still there however - you need to grind levels to unlock the better stuff. And even then the way the game is currently balanced in usual game modes it's nearly impossible to see a tank, unless you actively idle for reinforcement points. But where's the fun in that?Overall however the progress devs have made with this game is quite promising.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								***Update***Just got Men of War: Assault Squad 2, and it's amazing!  Defenitely recommend getting that game until Call to Arms is finished!Call to Arms is also great, and has the potential to be even better than MoW: AS2, but as it stands now, the current maps and missions can only hold one's interest for so long.Both are great games, and both should be owned.  Great job by the creators of these games!*Original Post*Pros:The AI doesn't seem to magically know where your unspotted troops are, so It's possible to setup actual ambushes and flank enemy positions without them already having troops aimed in on you (unlike WarGame: Red Dragon, where the AI sends troops straight towards your Command Vehicles hidden way off in the coner of the largest maps in extremely dense forests).The combat is very close to realistic without being too realistic (ex: higher caliber weapons will take out enemies with one or two good hits.Distance and hit location affect the effectiveness of projectiles (ex: a bullet from 100m will do less damage than one from 10m, and one bullet in the leg will not kill an enemy).Uses RNG, so the weapons don't have pin point accuracy every time (ex: squads can sprint or crawl from cover to cover under enemy fire and possibly survive.Most units carry medkits and can heal themselves as long as they're not incapacitated.Each unit can be controlled individually for better placement.Being able to manually control a unit from 3rd person is great (vehicles can be controlled in 1st person too).Cons (most of which maybe resolved in the final release):Balancing.  GRM is definitely superior to the USA.Riflemen don't shoot at vehicles that should easily be penetrated by bullets like technicals.Riflemen don't shoot at manned turrets even though you can manually aim and kill the gunners.You can literally spawn 1 technical at the beginning of the round and take out 4 AI players with just that vehicle.  Spawn a small squad after that, and you can cap their base.In Annialation, spawn points and bases are too close to the main battlefield.  Most matches can be won very quickly by capping the enemy base after whiping out their first few squads.Battlefields should be larger to accomodate the use of the modern weapons, especially for the vehicles.Some of the current maps have too much crammed together in small areas (ex: the middle area of the airfield and military base have way too many objects placed closely together...no room to strategically place troops).Use of artillery seems pointless at this point as the maps are too small to use it effectively.Don't know if much can be changed about the AI, but it just send troops straight towards objectives rather than going from cover to cover; so you can easily mow them down as they charge accross the open towards the objectives (They do however utilize cover once they get to the objective).It can be tricky trying to place troops on upper levels of buildings.My thoughts:Even in Alpha, this game is amazing.  I can't imagine how much fun it'll be once it's finished.  I didn't have Men of War...just saw Call to Arms by chance on steam and started reading up on it.  I was an avid fan of COH and was hoping this would fill the void...and it has.  At only $30 for deluxe...CtA is definitely worth it.  Hell, I'd pay $60 for it!  Great game!I've fiddled around with the editor a little as I'd like to eventually create my own maps and missions, but it will take time to be able to do that.  I can see the replayability of this game being virtually endless.I'm assuming the Multiplayer lobby doesn't have many players at the time since it's still alpha but hopefully that'll change.Even while still under development, it's one of the best strategy games I've ever played.  It took me about 2 days to understand how to play.  In all honestly, both CtA and MoW: AS2 are a must have as they both cover completely different times very well.  However, if you can only get one of them now, I think MoW: Assault Squad 2 would be the better buy.After watching Pixel playing MoW: AS2 with his buds, I'll definitely be getting it...hope CtA progresses to be just as good.

Early Access Review
								I recommend this game, its great fun, struggling with finding multiplayer servers here in Australia but I like to play the AI anyway.Buy it so that it advances faster. Make sure you buy the deluxe and download Sir Hinkels Campaigns fo SP fun.What can I say, the developers frequently update the game but it is totally playable and doesnt crash, they are just adding functionality weekly.A typical mission.Choose US start off with Marksmen to keep the enemy at bay. Kill enough enemy to get another squad, choose some US Assault team and storm the flag, move marksmen up to cover you from new enemy forces.Kill enough enemy to get another squad of Marksmen to assault another flag, try and get your assault squad to help them, get pinned down by enemy toyota with cannon on the back, pick some US support AT Troops, sneak up and blow up the Toyota, assault the flag, get another Marksment squad to cover you.What, enough points to get a Humvee, get humvee, take control by pressing Q and drive into enemy guns blazing, get blown up and die. Get another Hummer and hold back providing fire support, get another Marksmen squad over to flag 1 to support battled troops running low on ammo, kill enough to get another squad, Marines, hoohar. Storm the third flag with marines humvee and assault squad.Hold out...10/10 - would request the game adds "hoohar" button so I dont have to shout it every time I move them.

I get a billion notices that "video quality has been reduced to improve performance" while I play, if I even get through a game.  Crank it to Minimum...just as laggy, just as freezy, and have to close it out.However, I do see enough change in direction with the game mechanics to justify a new game. Hopefully it will become the best Men of war game yet. Or Perhaps this is a new series as the MOW moniker has been dropped.  Overall, I still recommend the game.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really like this game, still there are some issues.+Realism+Cool Graphics+Extremely detailed maps,objects,people+Fun Multiplayer with a lot of mods (+CO-OP CAMPAIGN)+A huge variety of weapons, vehicles and troopers+Map Editor-The game is heavy (for your device)-AI is not really smart (not exactly your opponents the AI, but the soldiers themselves-Lack of animations (animation for steady-look around/interact with weapon etc.)-Lack of voice acting- the campaign advicer does not talk, only subtitles and the phrases that the soldiers use are really annoying and not many-A lot of glitches that can ruin you the game like:       -If a car with a mounted weapon (highly used vehicle) is empty and you want somebody just on the gun you need 3 soldiers-first enters and goes to the driver seat, second becomes the sergaent of the car and the third goes on the gun and then you mount off the 1st and the 2nd       -If you have a damaged vehicle which has no crew in it and you want to repair it-the vehicle moves by vibrating and slowly going on a random position, so if you put an e.g. engineer to repair it and he sits by the vehicle, he soon gets glitched in it's hitbox and killed by the vibration even if the vehicle is moving in other direction (shortly the vehicle kills the repear time very often)-There is melee fighting but it is extremely stupid. They have knives which are only for throwing and do nothing-There isn't enough information about the squads you are purchasing e.g. it says Defensive Squad, yeah but what does it do, what men does it contain? It really has one medic which is extremely important and I think a machine gunner with the rest being just normal soldiers. Now those issues seem little, but if you play the game you will see they will bug you out. I still recommend the game, I had real fun while playing it and really enjoyed the AI opponents in skirmish. If you have a friend to play with, I highly recommend to play the cooperative campaign as it is real fun.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								A good game. High potential. A bit laggy and have some bugs ofcourse. I don't recommend it for people who don't enjoy RTS modern warfares(And for those who have anger problems for bugs and lag). The game doesn't deserve the full price 'yet'. But definetly worth to buy at a discount. Developers are nice and respond your issues as soon as possible. They keep updating units. I don't think they will abandon this game at all. Modern day units. Armored vehicles, sodiers, aircrafts. You won't find another strategy game having this much units and all fully controllable. Air warfare actually is very good but since the maps are not that huge, you cannot apply the real speeds of the aircrafts and they seem a bit weird while flying. But as I said, no way you can apply those speeds in a strategy game having slow ground units.Same/Similiar engine as Men of War(MoW) series but improvements of graphics and ofcourse the direct control engine make this game a unique one. This will be an epic modern warfare strategy game once it is completed.Hope it helps. Buy it & enjoy!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Open Beta Review Update:The game now has a Free2Play option, but it requires grinding for units and lacks singleplayer.  In addition they have added microtransactions, as more and more developers are on Steam.  On one hand I see F2P being good for boosting a dwindling population, but doubt it will last for long.As a deluxe edition supporter I don't have to worry about grinding for units, and get a couple extra factions for free.Development has certainly not been fast by any means, but a lot of the changes since early access, til now, have been quite nice.  Including improved vehichle controls and camera, more units and vehicles, and just general improvements to the game.I look forward to features such as individual unit/squad control. However, I feel if the game doesn't see some growth/sales, features like this may get cut.Overall this company is struggling and it's blindingly obvious. The F2P release is designed to encourage those users to buy XP packs in game, instead of having to buy the entire game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off I'm very disappointed so far with this game. However for the right price I will buy any MOW game and 8 dollars for the deluxe edition is a fair price. So why am I disappointed? Well, it's mostly due to the fact its MOW AS 2 and 1... in a modern tone. Think Red Rising but lower quality. That's the thing about Call to Arms it feels like a very good mod for AS. Expect the game deals with stupid AI issues the biggest one is vehicles will often engage units with either extreme force or none at all. Often I have lost a Bradley simply due to the dumb thing not attacking the technical with an SPG on it as it fires point blank at it. That or the Bradley will fire everything it has at the thing. Its almost insane how something that feels so mod like doesn't have a semi competent AI for a MOW game. (Note I have not tried online matches so this may just be a single player issue). That brings me to the next part the single player missions are boring after one play through and there are tons of small issues. (One which is very minor but is in black hawk down the pilot isn't a pilot he's a desc/units/etc...) Why is it that a modding community can do so much better at making a modern MOW with AS 2 then a company being paid?Now the good of the game.If the AI decides to be responsive then the fire fights are quite entertaining. Visuals and models are also nice to look at (Red Rising looks better but still a positive)Game hasn't crashed yetnew direct command is kinda cool but would prefer to be able to switch to old camera (checking what I damaged only to need to realign my shot gets very annoying)Still in Early Acess (Might be positive?)Overall Great game to get on the cheaps, If you own AS 2 just play Red Rising its overall a better experience currently but could change depending on how they continue with the game

content:

Early Access Review
								25$ is a bit much, so pick it up when its ont sale.Other than that this is a really fun game. I hate Most strategy games because they feel like you aren't a high expirienced player, playing against other just as good players. they just feel like a resource race to see who can build their army faster.Call To Arms is different in the sence that instead of just sending units in and hoping you placed them in the right spots for the fight. You can take controll of an individual, and aim/move/fire leaving you feeling like you are actually made a difference in the firefight.Playing 3v3 with some freinds and each game was around 40-60 mins. and alot of it was pretty fun.The controls are kinda iffy tough. Its really fun to take aim and shoot, but its pretty hard to do anything else with them.Tanks are really well balanced. They can dominate the game but one well placed rocket scores you tons of points takes them out pretty easy.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell: ARMA III meets Company of Heroes 2 behind the Men of War Engine..... get ready to Lock N'Load. First and foremost, I purchased the Deluxe Edition and as such get the goods that come with it. It is free to play with the minimal gaming experience devoid of extra factions and customization. I have no problem with this as I like the developer and I like the game; thus I bought it. To all those butthurt individuals out there, they obviously didn'r read what is in the F2P version.I really enjoy this game not only becuase of the credibility of the Men of War franchise but also becuase Call to Arms brings the game time-period 21st century. That being said, if you have played Men of War then you are fully aware of what this game is and what it can be. If you are new to the Men or War franchise as I was when I purchased it, then you need to be ready for a potentially punishing (yet tremendously satisfying) learning curve regarding weapon ranges and their potential to devastate both armoured and soft targets. The name of the game is find cover and fire and maneuver ladies and gentlemen; if you don't get this concept then learn it quick! Overall, great game and I highly recommend it to any person that has a love for RTS and realistic gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I won't go into great detail with this one, I'll try summarize my opinion, if this review is vague please scroll down or up for a better more detailed review, currently I'll give this game as much effort as I see fit to warn the masses of it's issues.Graphics - The Graphics are just fine in my opinion, but then again I run the game on the lowest settings because if you experience any sort of frame rate drop the game automatically lowers the graphical settings to the point where if you're playing at 100% maxed out settings you can go so low as to have 1% lowest settings. Irregardless the graphics also seem to be fairly taxing for a simplistic type of game, when it comes to the other MoW games I own I usually only experience frame rate drops when I'm in the midst of an entire town exploding due to artillery and rockets soaring all over knocking buildings and blocks of structures down.Gameplay - This one is gonna be pretty broad so bare with me, The game play at it's core is like any other MoW title, heck it reminds me a lot of MoW Assault Squad 2, which is a good thing considering that's probably the best MoW game (At least in my opinion.) but here's where things get complicated, it reminds me at it's core of the good ol Assault Squad 2 game, but it plays differently enough that it's noticable, and not the good kind of noticeable. When you try to manually control a vehicle you may as well kiss your FPS goodbye as you'll be giving up your standard view for a third person view, to be expected, but you'll have an absolutely hideous hud that looks like it was ripped from the Abrams Tank's internal view from Battlefield 3, there's a huge disgusting sight with bright green bars all over making it rather impossible to even see what you're looking at, in addition you're locked in behind the unit camera wise, you HAVE to play the manual control like this, it's atrocious and it hurts to do it so I just use vehicles by telling them to fire on specific spots and hoping the AI can do it since I can't. As for infantry I believe they're mostly untouched but in all honesty I barely even think to use infantry since they auto aim and kill everything in seconds usually so why bother. Besides the third person manual control aim looking garbage the gameplay itself feels... unfinished (obviously) but even more so for a game that's in early access, this game has been in early access for a year or two now at least and it's made... "progress" and it just feels like gameplay isn't the main focus though I know it is, reading the patches they've turned the game around at least partially but the game itself is still pretty bare bones and not very entertaining, the worst part probably in my opinion is the sound design.Sound Design - Yup this was bound to happen, so the sounds "for the most part" sound okay, if you're not used to actual gun sounds some of these will sound fine to you, but if you're a hardcore gun fanatic (which I am not) you'd notice there are distinctly♥♥♥♥♥♥sounds for AKs, M4s etc. Vehicles sound "okay" I just wish the American's APCs didn't sound like they were powered by the same Jet Engine the Abrams has. Moreover the voices are absolutely garbage, they literally ported the U.S. voices from any of the MoW games over to this, and can someone inform these clearly not American devs that Americans don't shout "FOR THE MOTHERLAND!" as their battle cry, it's a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and insulting. And can you guys actually get a real American English speaking voice actor for this, because whoever that guy is you can practically hear his accent breaking as he tries to keep in American.Units:Vehicles - Well I'll hand it to them, they put two different types of Abrams tanks in the game, kudos for that, but the real issue is, to get even one, is gonna cost you an arm, a leg and about half your brain in in game resource points, you'll have barely enough to call two more squads of infantry. Also can someone explain to me why a T-60 can knock out an Abrams from the front? cause I'm almost certain that's viably impossible to do from any angle. Other than that there is so major imbalances between vehicles for instance a humvee with an M60 feels a lot more like a pickup truck than the pickup truck feels with it's PKM. In addition no aircraft, unsurprisingly, all those screenshots you may have seen?, yeah those are just part of the background don't get hyped you can't use a blackhawk to drop airborne to my knowledge. Infantry and support teams - Machine gun team? what's that? cause it's not in this game. Yeah were you expecting some burly American with an M60 or maybe a .50 cal tri pod on either side?, no?, just me then. Infantry come in a couple of flavors: Common infantry like riflemen in the U.S. Army, Pre Elite infantry like the U.S. marines, and scummy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t way too powerful needs to be nerfed camo'd invisi super accurate invulnerable infantry aka the terrorist Assassin ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. AT troops consist of about 3-4 standard riflemen and one guy with the AT rocket launcher, either RPG or AT4, now for some weird reason the AT4 is only a one shot one use rocket which means once the U.S. AT guy is out of his launchers he's down to being infantry, and no you can't rearm these guys with trucks, you can resupply ammo from trucks so long as they aren't explosives, oh but he's something handy if you get an APC it comes chock full of AT4s, at least three of em for the U.S. so if you want more rockets for the AT guy, either go kill him off and get another AT Squad or waste all of your resources on a useless APC to get three more. And don't get me started on the types of tanks and how A modern era main battle tank can be taken out by some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hand cranked turreted Russian hunk of♥♥♥♥♥♥like a T 60.Lastly the game's playerbase! - Where is it!?, where is everyone?, am I the only one here?, yeah it's barebones no one plays this online as they shouldn't, the game isn't great, it's no wonder no one bothers to play it, it's a hassle to play the damn thing and to find someone competent who wants to play to the end is very rare.Last last thing, yes yes it's got a single player mode, you can click the misleading "online" session and throw bots into a match like most everyone does so that they can at least play a full game. Oh and the campaign is misleading what it means is a nigh impossible single mission which teases you to the possiblity of two or three more missions behind it but when you need to manually fire using that horrible hud in third person, yeah no don't even bother it's a pain physically to play. Summary : Not worth it currently, it's updates every now and then and in huge patches which is good, but right this second the game just has so many problems with it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								i play men of war alot. i think the initive that the ai take depending on the enemy and situation was amazing. betwwen men of war and company of heroes its hard to pick the best game.  now moving on to this game. i tried so hard to have high hopes, i tried so hard to ignore bad reviews and enjoy the game. here is the problem. the game is broken. the enemy ai are either a. overpowered or b. stay at they spawn point with an absurb amount of vehicles. the vehicles are practically useless. an abrams tank should not die by an armored car with a 20 mm auto cannon.  the direct control feature is pointless. your charcter either attempts to walk backwards on fail to aim at all resulting in your swift death.Prosmodern setting.modern weapons.freeCons:every single thingbuggy aiun responsive ai teammates and enemiesoverpowered enemy aiai in generalforget single playeryeah basically everything is wrong. The verdict? skip this game. save yourself the trouble and stick to men of war trust me on that.now now if you are one of those but i like modern vehicles and i like a realistic setting i got great news for youhere are 3 modern rts games done rightWorld in conflict: i cant stress how great this game is.company of heroes with the modern combat mod. oh whats that? never heard of it? ok well picture company of heroes literally reskinned with modern units and vehicles.and wargame for those who like to massive managenow on a side note. this game has so so much great potential but it falls shorti recommend dropping the fps direct control and stick with the overhead view.more urban environmentsmore vehicles weapons and unitsrewrite the whole ai........ just use men of war and reskin it with modern units for godsake. Do us all a favor.

Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
First of all if you like tactical rts games - this is the real thing :) Just got to give this a positve review! I don't do this often - but I think most of the recent negative reviews are not legit. (I usually don't support any kind of dlc crap or f2p or even pay to win!)  The fact that it is f2p now is great! It means much more players on the servers and a growing playerbase - everybody can try the games multiplayer for free.	 Which brings players to mp, is a nice demo and even solidarity! I own the fullversion and paid for it two weeks before the change to f2p. I don't regret it! I can use the workshop, the games editor and can access the singleplayer and multiplayer. Market seems fine - no pay2win here. All in all the EA is well done, maybe lags some content and has its flaws but even without new ui, sandbags :/ more nations and stuff it feels great and the final version will easily be the best title of the Series when it comes to solid gameplay :)As an old school gamer who played every mow and related title I must say it is the best quality gameplay running on the engine. I modded a lot back in the days, therefore I must admit development goes slow (should be 1.0 allready^^) but for a small indi dev. its ok to be late if the quality of the product is fine.( And no there are no AS2 mods that well coded with hd models (not ripped off from other games!) Pathfinding for example is a mess (vets remember the suicide blitz^^) even in AS2, its much better in CTA and will hopefully be flawless in the final version. Same for balancing. So nothing to worry I will even buy the DLC to keep'em going...Good Job DMS!CheersTo the latest bad reviews from players with play times like a few hrs what is up with you guys - honestly? --> complaints about empty servers but against f2p !!!--> "I paid - so I want my money back! - 'cause it is f2p now" (just a hint try reading dev notes! It can help!) --> without even understanding the f2p model or the market system you are complaining about --> and finally all this while swallowing real scammy business models from the major publishers...❥ :steamhappy:

content:
Posted: March 25
Early Access Review
								Once again, the GJW's (Gamer Justice Warriors) are out in force trying to tank a good game by flooding it with negative reviews based on one business decision, and mentioning nothing of the game itself.  This always happens when developers make some decision that players disagree with, and in this case the GJW's are even further off-base than usual.First, I have to address the thing that all of the negative reviews are harping on: no, they did not rip anybody off by suddenly going F2P.  Just stop.  The play options in the free version of CtA are adequately limited.  Most F2P models are so much worse.  Just be glad it isn't like CoH2 where you have to spend about $1000 to have all of the factions and leaders.   But more importantly, this is a good RTS with original concepts, and the developers deserve to be supported for making it.   You don't have to buy it in EA, but any fan of RTS or military games owes it to themselves to at least check out the free version.  If you see yourself playing it for 100 hours or more, pick it up on a sale.  Like now.  With the current drought of good and original RTS games, RTS fans need to support games like this.  I liked Grey Goo, but I want to see new things in the genre.  I doubt very many people are going to play hundreds of hours on the free version without ever wanting to play co-op, single player, or user-created content.  But if they want to, so be it.  You still have everything you paid for.  Just be glad they're trying to bring more people into a dying genre.  For that purpose, it's actually a great model.  I'm willing to pay $20 for the full experience because I love single-player RTS.  Not to mention, because I believe in supporting developers who make games I enjoy.  But I have no problem with F2P models that work, and I could see this model being very successful for an RTS multi-player game.  Would DOTA and LoL be as big without F2P?   I should mention I am aware of the MoW series, so I know that CtA is not a completely new and original thing.  But MoW is how old now?  It's time for an update, and there aren't a lot of developers making a serious effort in the RTS arena.  Even fewer are offering an RTS with direct unit control and seamless transitions from birds-eye to 3rd, and all the way into 1st person camera.  There area a couple of games doing similar things, but none of them are pulling it off in a mil-sim setting like CtA.  The modern mil-sim aspect is something I really appreciate.  Nothing against fantasy or medieval settings, but we don't get a lot of strategy games with a grown-up, realistic feel.  In CtA, the men are proportional to their surroundings, and all of their actions have detailed and specific animations.  For example, when a soldier is bandaging himself, he looks like he's bandaging himself.  When he's taking cover, he looks like he's taking cover.  Etc, etc.  They use weapons and vehicles that are authentic to their real-life counterparts.  Overall it's a very cohesive and authentic look, just needs a bit of polishing.  Another knock against the game I've seen is that it's a "dumbed down" version of MoW.  I don't think that's the case at all.  It may appear that way because it's still in EA, but the unit controls are still plenty deep.  To be honest, I thought the controls in MoW were far more complex than they needed to be, and not very intuitive.  It was the biggest barrier keeping me from playing them more.  The controls in CtA are much more streamlined and intuitive.  I was actually able to jump into a skirmish and play without having to consult the keybindings for 10 minutes.  Granted, I still had to check them in order to be effective, but they are much more digestible.  Caveat emptor, I will say the game still feels like an Early Access game.  But... it is, so I won't thumb it down for that.  There is some work to be done with optimization and generally polishing things up, but the core gameplay is there and it's fun.  I have been starving for something like this, and CtA is doing a great job of scratching a very particular itch.  I usually tend to write too much, so I'll try to cut it off here.  Bottom line: any fan of RTS or military games owes it to themselves to at least check out the free version.  If you have any interest in these games, I'm confident you won't be disappointed.  If you don't like the game, you can let us know why in your negative review.  I can understand dogpiling on somebody like UBISOFT for some of the stuff they do, but the GJW's are out of line this time.  This game deserves some love from the RTS community, in the form of upward thumbs and units sold.  The fact that it has "Mixed" reviews right now is a mark of shame on all of us!  Shame!  Shame!  Shame!  Shame!

								I've played Call to Arms for a short time, I know it's not enough to make a fair judgement of a game that is actually a mod to Men of War:Vietnam, I found this out when one of the soldiers yelled out "For Uncle Sam!" That's the same line in Men of War:Vietnam. I could have easily played the real Men of War game than this, but this game does come with a nice look for a game and it's not at all bad, it's impressive for a mod that's for sure, only wish that everyone else could see it. Though, most of the reviews were people who've most likely not even played Men of War, this is a good alternative to it at best. Seeing as the game plays just like Men of War if not better with a First Person mode when controlling a soldier, easily switch from third person to first, though it's a little...clunky. The soldier doesn't happen to fire about half the time when you fire, sprinting is jagged as well.Now, the game is fun, yes, but it still has some things to fix, which is what you can expect from an Early Access game. I'm sure it will be fully fleshed out once it's fully complete.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Don't know enough about this yet to make a decision?Its a top down styled rts which has features a akin to that of games like Commandos 3. Variable camera angles and the ability to take command of your soldier individually or a vehicles and correct its aim for better accuracy in exchange for a loss of perspective on the larger scale battle. This is where Command and Conquer meets Commandos with a squirt of Company of Heroes. If you like games like ARMA 3 and Company of Heros this is the hybrid for you. It literally feels like you were to put Commandos' character contol into the engine of Company of Heroes within the evironment of the Arma 3 RHS mod. Some of the more intimate character commands are a but tricky and less responsive than to be desired but for it's current state ad an easrly access feature it has enough controlability and content, not to mention the already growing Workshot Content, to warrant several hours worth of addictive gameplay per session. As someone completely new to the franchise, this is a refreshing game with a unique mili-sim / sector control / conquest / survival cornerstone to its foundation. Worth the money to pay for it in its current state. As mentioned there are bugs and some frustrating mechanics for individual unit functions but we can only hope they will be smoothened out. == pro's & cons ==My biggest con about the game  is that this may not be for friends who live far apart to play together. When I was uploading to my youtube channel whilst playing this my entire lobby suffered lag that would cause the game to stop momentarily, quite often, when my ping surpassed 350ms. When not uploading and having enough free bandwidth to keep my ping below 80ms there were no issues. I havent tested any further ranges of ping between.My biggest pro woul dbe that to play this with your friends is one of the most interesting and engaging games to participate in as a team. Roles can be given or you can just play it your own way. Theres are so many playstyle possibilites for this. You can choose to just control a small group of specialists and leave the rest of the companies within your force to be managed by your team mates or you can choose to have a little bit of everything. Do you prefer to play the sniper elite or the vehicle company or do you want to play them all?I reccommend this game, for its target audience; which would be people who want a milisim / rts  or as close as they can get to it.

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								Get it if you're a fan of the MoW games and always wanted a modern era game from the MoW series, it's still in early access but I haven't encountered a single crash or a bug that made the game unplayable.The biggest issues I found with the game was the AI and its pathfinding, sometimes enemy or friendly AI will get stuck in places or completely stop moving their vehicles mid-game, but nothing too bad as the vehicles could still fire at anything that moved into their range.The current units look pretty good with a lot of detail, both infantry and vehicles, animations are a bit lacking and could use more polish, but again, it's an early access title, saying that doesn't mean much since everything still needs polish.Hopefully through out the development the game will lose more and more of the MoW look, like the UI and voice lines are straight from the MoW series so the game still gives a sort of feeling that it's just a modern era mod for the MoW games instead of being a full game of its own.if you're interested in the game, then get it, it'll help the developers finish it properly, too many early access games are being abandoned by devs these days, but at least these guys are ready to go through with it, they interact with the community, answer questions on the forums and even made me reconsider my opinion of the game as my previous review was negative.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								For being in early access, this game is great. The previous bugs of vehicle combat, not being able to look up when in direct control of a vehicle, and various other issues have been resolved. So far there is a full roster of infantry units with multiple light vehicles and two medium vehicles, an IFV and a "medium tank" per faction. Even though the selection is small, as is to be expected, everything is well balanced. So far i havent found a glitch, big or small. Cover works well. AI seems greatly improved over MOWAS, never played AS2. Instead of having to rearm each unit with specific ammo types, units near ammo crates automatically refill their small arms ammo. I do not think that grenades refill, but im pretty sure that RPG and other forms of AT rounds do. Will test this theory. Also most AFV's have the ability to resupply infantry ammo and most come with three AT rockets which is nice. There are a couple really good player created missions, namely SirHinkels. His missions were very well polished, challenging but balanced, and exceptionally fun to play. All in all, I'd say that this game is definitely worth getting, and should be on everyones radar.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dispite the fact i own all the MoW titles, soldiers and most of the outhergames these guys have produced in the past i was a little put off bythe large amount of neg reviews in the community hub. most of theso-called early acess games i have tryed in the past have been blatentmoney grabs. I have followed the development and have now installedthe free multiplayer function. I do see progress being made, slow, butprogress none the less. This alone puts it far ahead of the "outher" early acess games, most of them anyway. A couple of things however that stop me paying full price right now are1. Reports that you have to P 2 W now the multiplayer is free.2. I have acess to very little actual content so it is hard to formulate an informed opinion regarding content, present and future.3. the progress is very slow, only 2 factions, limited units for those factions and a limited amount of maps.4. You have to buy "gold edition" to get the single player op's.5. changes to the "direct conrtol" feature that did NOT need changingfrom MoW AS2.Now here is what i do like.1. the same great gameplay on a well known game engine.2. The units that are there work well, Vehicles work well, MOSTLY.An abrams getting stuck on a light pole or tiny rock is amusing forthe FIRST TIME ONLY.3. So far (for me) these guys are a "trusted" company.4. The game modes for the most part work well andco-op missions are smoother as you actually get the units you orderinstead of being randomly spawned to ANY player on your team.5. Dev's that are active in the game and the forums is not onlya good thing but quite rare these days.In summary, I DO like this game. If it were finished i would pay the full price,that being said there are NO guarentees that it will ever be finished.I love the intensity in combat, As a former member of the ADF I appreciate the way ranged weapons work and the few indirect fire weapons seem to workproperly too. many games either nerf them to useless or make them wayyyyto op. Auto grenade launchers ARE really that good. AT weapons work ok when theunit remembers they have them.....From what i can see most of the issues are to be expected of an early acess gameso it is unfair to list the multitude of bugs in-game right now as faults in the gameas i am sure they will be resolved eventually. That last word... Eventually is the mainreason i will NOT pay full price right now. Whats next, early acess hamburgers? would you order a burger and pay for it months before you want it or need it, How about a car? I think letting people play multi for free is a smart move, the game will fail without a strong playerbase this is why i think it costs too much for what you get right now.Also the early acess dev's that came before you have not helped, Early acess has come  to mean "cash grab" for many.I am going to give a tentative recommend for this game, based on pedigree mainlyand the small but solid content i see so far.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well to start, everyone looking at this should be aware that it is in an alpha, problems will occur. However, I have only ran into 1 so far: an invincible enemy soldier.  Pros - Is probably one of the few if not the only modern strategy game where the only strategy isn't to make fourty of every unit and just throw it all at the enemy's base. You must use caution and use your units wisely.- Kind of goes with the above statement. Armored units are not abundant, you cannot throw armor at the enemy like in "World in Conflict" and hope you win. With that being said, World in Conflict is still a very good game.- Ammo: In the original Men of War and Assault Squad 1, you had to drag ammo to each individual soldier, this gets tiresome when you have an entire army to re-arm. In Call to Arms, soldiers are automatically rearmed when close to an ammo box, no more pointless dragging.- Realistic units and weapons: Has many up to date firearms and vehicles. Should please gun nuts and vehicle gurus alike.Cons- Currently limited in terms of actual gameplay, only 4 SP missions currently, and a few more MP maps. but it is still in alpha so it's not that big of deal.- Audio: Currently uses Men of War's voices and weapon audio (cant say for all weapons). Again, hopefully this will be changed in the beta or final release.- Bugs: have only ran into 1 bug (invincible enemy) not that big of deal but I did have to restart the map.- Workshop- currently a lot of the workshop content is unusable as they need to be updated, but that can change at any moment.To finish, it is a great game for a person wanting a modern strategy game that doesn't involve spamming 30,000 tanks and attacking the enemy. You will need to strategize. Also, GET THE DELUXE VERSION, save yourself $5.00 and just get the deluxe to begin with. I would strongly recommend this game to my friends.

								I really wanted to like this game, but I sadly cannot recommend it at this point. 3/10Don't let the screenshots fool you, it's essentially a modded version of MOW: Assault Squad, updating it from WWII to modern day. I'm sure this will improve with time.I've been following the developer blogs for a few months, and while they do have great 'plans' for the future, I'm not convinced it's enough to open my wallet for.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well I don't know what happened to my first review for this game but whatever.So where to begin. Lets start with the F2P thing as people currently don't understand it. The F2P version only incudes multiplayer, not the campaign nor does it work with mods, if you pay for the game you get all of this and the fact that you know you are supporting the developers create this already amazing game.Next, onto the new update. There have been lots of new and cool features added into the game. Now you are able to play as the infantry in 3rd person which is really fun and I enjoy it alot. The also upgraded the textures and graphics from what I can tell. It also runs smoother now, I mean it ran smooth before but now there is now problems whatsoever.Now the season pass, I myself have not purchased the deluxe edition nor the season pass but I do plan to. Basically the deluxe edition gives you early access to stuff while in the beta as well as some items to show that you own the deluxe edition. And the season pass, the Devs have confirmed that they will not be releasing DLC during early access, however once the game is finished they plan on releasing new campaigns such as a Russian and German campaign as DLC. It is much like what Rainbow Six Siege did, if you purchase the Season Pass you will recieve betas for the new DLC as well as the fully finished DLC early. Not a bad deal if you ask me.And finally the game itself, graphically the game looks really well done. The UI looks really cool and it feels like a modern version of MoW: AS2's UI. And with the recent update the textures as I said before have all be upgraded. Soundwise the game is pretty good, the music is really well done and the weapon fire sound like their realife counterparts. Now for the real question, "How does the game itself play out?". Well the answer to that is simple, it is much like MoW: AS2. It is very obvious that this is a modern version of MoW: AS2 which I really like. All is all the gameplay is very fun and well done. Congrats to the devs for making this game as great as it is.Final Rating: 9/10My main reason for not giving it 10/10 is because of a current lack of content but hat can be expected with a game in early access. Once more content is added in I will update the review. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								came back to rewrite this, i been playing the crap out of this after initially being disspointed. i had to remind myself that this is in fact early access, so the lack of content is no longer surprising. the combat is hard but rewarding. using actual tactics like support by fire, flanking, bounding etc actually leads to victory. so lets do pros and consPros:- attention to detail is pretty neat. in the real world US army support units (aviation, transport, etc) often still get issued m16a4's while front line grunts will have m4's. this holds true in call to arms. - using tactics leads to victory. support by fire, flanking, bounding etc. actually help you win. you dont just simply send in all your troops onto the X and let it play out. - the games seem fairly balanced most of the time- gameplay is just flatout fun- the market place already has content, so it shows the potential for a good community Cons: - for some this might be a con so i will list it, not using tactics will lead to your demise. if you dont want to micro manage your units then this game is not for you. if you dont, you will probably loose a lot. - its early access and thus it still lacks content. no vehicles in at the moment so its strictly infantry combat- no singleplayer campaign, just MP pvp. you do have the option to enable bots though so you can setup singleplayer matches in a multiplayer environment.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								An interesting take on Men of War, there are a lot of great new features, and a couple of controversial ones. It's still pretty early in development and thus fairly rough around the edges, but this is an established company with a proven track record; Not some sketchy indie dev. For better or worse, the game WILL reach a completed state at some point. Gameplay wise, if you're familiar with Men of War, it's more of the same, though not quite a straight reskin. Infantry combat is faster and more micro intensive, troop numbers are considerably lower, and the Special Unit category is entirely missing(Which has it's own pros and cons, most notably it's impact on the pacing of multiplayer, especially in 1v1). Overall, despite some of it's more glaring downsides(Namely unlock progression, a gimmick forced in to the series at Assault Squad 2 and carried over despite loads of outcry, as you've probably read from a sea of negative reviews by now.), I can't help but recommend it. It's Men of War in a new setting, a refreshing break from the constant shilling of WW2 that most war-themed games seem comfortable to graze in endlessly.Pros:-UI improvements-Better take on direct control for vehicles.-New setting allows for more creativity and diversity.-Fairly tight and balanced. Could easily become competitive if nurtured properly by the developer.-Various 'quality of life' improvements over Assault Squad.-Combat is more than just a reskin. Has an entirely different feel to unit behaviour.-Vehicles are extremely satisfying to use, and come with new quirks and weapons unique to the time frame.-More interesting campaign missions(That are playable in coop)-Reshuffling of unit hierarchy. No more cheap autocannon spam.-No more Brandenburgers(This is a selling point all of it's own. Seriously DMS, those things are beyond broken in AS2)-No more Brandenburgers 2: Electric Boogaloo. No seriously, ♥♥♥♥ these things.Cons:-Unlock Progression. Terrible, utterly terrible post-2007 gimmick shoe-horned into every multiplayer game in existence. Has absolutely no place in an RTS and will 100% kill the matchmaking if it's mandatory for ranked play like in AS2. Forces everyone to play lobby matches to turn it off in Assault Squad.-Currently no option to turn off Unlock Progression even in lobby matches. Forces everyone to grind like some Korean MMO or Call of Duty. Seriously, no one wants this, DMS.-As with all RTS games, Barrier to entry is high if you don't have the patience and humility to learn and tank a few losses early on. Lack of a tutorial of any sort exacerbates the issue, with Unlock Progression being a cheesy means to slap a bandaid on the issue by restricting what units you can buy.-Units have no descriptions, but have their specification stats filled out. How hard is it to take an hour to type in 2-3 sentences per unit briefly explaining what they are/what they do? Especially after taking the trouble to fill out their stats. Buying units is guesswork when you're first learning, unlocks or no, just to find out what equipment they carry. I recommend starting a solo match in test mode.-Still a heavy work in progress. Don't come in expecting a finished product needing a few tweaks here and there. It's got a long way to go before it catches up to it's precessors in content, and with only two factions, it's going to need a MUCH larger unit roster.Even with all it's problems, I've had a positive experience. As it exists now, however, I'd only recommend it for RTS or Men of War enthusiasts. It's got a long way to go before it properly competes with others of the franchise, let alone the genre.
